programs.description: A large cluster of input genes collectively regulate mitosis in glioblastoma cells including kinetochore-microtubule attachments, spindle assembly, chromosome segregation, and cytokinesis. This program encompasses both normal cell division and the hyperproliferative phenotype in malignancy.

citation.notes: TTK (MPS1), BUB1, BUB1B, KNL1, and related checkpoint components upregulated in glioblastoma.
BUB1B is functionally required for glioblastoma proliferation and poor prognosis.
NDC80, SKA3, CENPF, CENPE required for stable kinetochore attachments implicated in GBM progression.
NDC80 and SKA components regulate mitosis and cell cycle in glioblastoma.
ESPL1 (separase) and associated proteins trigger chromosome segregation at anaphase.
Separase activation (ESPL1) cleaves cohesin to allow chromatid separation.
ECT2, RACGAP1, KIF23, PRC1 coordinate contractile ring formation and midbody assembly.
KIF14 and PRC1 interaction necessary for cytokinesis efficiency.
Single-cell modeling reveals spindle components critical in glioblastoma cell fate decisions.

programs.evidence_summary: Large-scale studies confirm most of these genes are differentially upregulated and functionally promote both normal mitosis and the malignant proliferative state in glioblastoma cells, with strong genetic and functional validation.

citations.notes: Hub genes CDK1, BUB1B, NDC80, CCNB1, TOP2A, DLGAP5, ASPM all correlate to glioblastoma progression.
Bioinformatics and animal models confirm CENPF, PBK, ASPM, KIF2C, KIF20A, CDC20, TOP2A among highest expressed in glioma and associated with cell cycle progression.
BUB1B required for GBM proliferation and survival; poor prognosis.
MAD2, BUB3—core checkpoint components not specified in input but required for spindle checkpoint signaling.

programs.program_name: Cell Cycle Progression and DNA Replication
programs.description: Cell cycle checkpoint regulators, cyclins, and DNA replication/repair enzymes are highly expressed, ensuring cell cycle entry and DNA synthesis in malignant glioblastoma. Aberrations drive uncontrolled proliferation and therapy resistance.

citation.notes: Cell cycle and apoptosis pathways dysregulated in glioblastoma.
RRM2, regulated by BRCA1, protects GBM cells from replication stress, promotes tumorigenicity.
EXO1 key DNA repair player, critical for genomic stability and tumor evolution.
BRIP1 (FANCJ) recruitment and regulation of FANCD2 in DNA damage responses; functions in genome maintenance.
DEGs enriched in nucleoplasm, protein binding, ATP binding—core for DNA replication and cell cycle control.

programs.evidence_summary: Meta-analyses and mechanistic studies confirm overexpression of cell cycle and DNA replication/repair genes is necessary for GBM proliferation and associated with poor patient outcome.

citations.notes: BRCA1-RRM2 axis maintains replication capacity and tumorigenicity in GBM.
EXO1 DNA repair activity implicated as biomarker and driver of tumor evolution.
Cell cycle checkpoints key to glioblastoma therapy resistance.
BRCA1, FANCD2—essential partners with BRIP1 for DNA repair not present in input list.

programs.description: Genes such as HMMR, ASPM, MKI67, FOXM1, and MELK maintain the stemness, self-renewal, and tumorigenic capacity of glioblastoma cells, contributing to resistance and recurrence.

citation.notes: HMMR supports self-renewal and tumorigenic potential of glioblastoma stem-like cells.
FOXM1 promotes proliferation, EMT, invasion, stemness in glioblastoma.
MELK regulates FOXM1 phosphorylation, essential for glioma stem cell proliferation.
Ribosome metabolism supports glioma stem cell properties and tumor proliferation.

predicted_cellular_impact: Increased tumor initiation, recurrence, and resistance
Maintenance of glioma stem cell populations
programs.evidence_summary: Functional studies reveal that knockdown of HMMR, ASPM, FOXM1, and MELK impairs tumor growth and stemness; their expression correlates with poor prognosis and resistance.

citations.notes: HMMR critical in GBM stemness; targeting HMMR impairs self-renewal capacity.
MELK-FOXM1 axis essential for glioma stem cell proliferation.
ASPM overexpression in glioma correlates with poor prognosis; regulated by FOXM1.
SOX2 master stem cell regulator impacted by FOXM1, required for maintenance but not present in input list.

clustering_basis: Meta-analyses of prognostic and functional studies
method.notes: Programs derived by grouping input genes by their shared involvement in mitosis/cytokinesis, cell cycle, DNA repair, or stemness, then cross-validating these clusters against high-throughput glioblastoma datasets and recent functional genomic studies.
